page.title: 06The Cockerham Sea Wall
page.content: Protecting the area from the ravages of the tides stands the Sea Wall, a structure approx.10ft.high,40ft.thick at base and 3.25miles long constructed of sand and clay faced with blocks and pitched.Its origins are obscure,but maintained by the Estate until 1926, thence by a farmers co-operative, Crookhey Estate Embankment Committee, ceded to the River Lune Catchment Board in 1948,latterly managed by the NWWA.Dissected by 3 drainage channels ,all with water operated sea doors, Bank End Pool,Patty's Pool and the River Cocker with extra electrically operated doors.A new wall,privately financed,South of R. Cocker was built and washed away in 1977, flooding a vast area.The NWWA took over the project and a wall,completed 1980, reclaimed 125acres,with an SSSI of 17acres conserved for Natterjack Toad.
